channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indictments Accuse 44 in Minnesota of Brazen Pandemic Aid Fraud
item.description: The Justice Department said the defendants had stolen $240 million intended to feed children, in what appears to be the largest theft so far from a pandemic-era program.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Chandan Khanna/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The indictments said the defendants had pulled in millions of dollars a week by taking money from federal anti-hunger programs for meals they never served.

item.title: Trump’s Lawyers Skirt Question of Declassification in Documents Case
item.description: The former president insists he shouldn’t have to state in a legal proceeding that he declassified the documents, while casting doubt on whether they remain classified.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: No credible evidence has emerged to support former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he had a standing order to declassify everything he took from the Oval Office.

item.title: Videos Show Trump Allies Handling Georgia Voting Equipment
item.description: The footage raises new questions about efforts by Trump affiliates in a number of swing states to gain access to and copy sensitive voting software after the 2020 election.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim, Richard Fausset and Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Sarah Koenig, the Host of ‘Serial,’ Talks About Adnan Syed’s Release
item.description: We talk with Sarah Koenig, host of the “Serial” podcast.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed, whose case was chronicled on the podcast “Serial,” exited the courthouse to a crowd of supporters on Monday.

item.title: ‘Serial:’ Season 1
item.description: A high school senior named Hae Min Lee disappeared one day after school in 1999, in Baltimore County, Md. A month later, her body was found in a city park. She’d been strangled. Her 17-year-old ex-boyfriend, Adnan Syed, was charged with murder, and within a year, he was sentenced to life in prison. The case against him was largely based on the story of one witness, Adnan’s friend Jay, who testified that he had helped Adnan bury Hae’s body. But Adnan has always maintained that he had nothing to do with Hae’s death. Some people believe he has been telling the truth. Many others don’t.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: The Enduring Wisdom of ‘Goodnight Moon’
item.description: It’s the first book many babies receive as a gift, and one of the few that parents will keep when their child is grown. Why does this 75-year-old story have such staying power?
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan

item.title: Will Cheri Beasley’s North Carolina Senate Race Break Democratic Hearts Again?
item.description: Since a blue wave in the state in 2008, winning elections hasn’t been easy for Democrats. But polling is evenly divided as Cheri Beasley and Ted Budd compete.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheri Beasley arriving for a campaign event at Johnson C. Smith University in Charlotte, N.C., on Friday. She is running for Senate as a judge above the fray.

item.title: N.Y.C. Subway System to Install Security Cameras in Train Cars
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said the installations, which grew from a pilot project after a mass shooting in Brooklyn, would allay riders’ anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stations in the subway system are outfitted with cameras, but cars have been a blind spot.

item.title: N.Y.C. Ends Private Employer Vaccine Mandate
item.description: Mayor Eric Adams received the new booster on Tuesday, as he ended the Covid vaccine mandate and continued to roll back pandemic restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hebrew Home at Riverdale in New York began administering the new bivalent booster shots to residents and workers last week.

item.title: The Godwit’s 7,000-Mile Journey: A Migration That Breaks Records
item.description: Researchers marvel at the bird’s record-holding migratory flight of 7,000 or so miles from Alaska to New Zealand at this time of year. No eating or refueling along the way.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins
item.media:credit: Malcolm Schuyl/Alamy
item.media:description: Looking for an endless summer, the bar-tailed godwit flies 7,000 miles each year, from Alaska to New Zealand, to breed and raise its young.

item.title: Apps Like Flashfood and Too Good to Go Let You Buy Food That Was Going to be Thrown Away
item.description: Several companies say they are tackling food waste by connecting people with unsold food from restaurants and grocery stores.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Lawrence Agyei for The New York Times

item.title: For New Yorkers, 6 p.m. Is the New 8 p.m.
item.description: Why are restaurants in the city filling up at hours that were once unfashionably early?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Sugar and Jane Dickson

item.title: Is America Really in a Mental Health Crisis?
item.description: Many in power would prefer to kick questions like “What caused the mental health crisis?” and “Who benefits?” out of sight. Don’t let them.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Carr
item.media:credit: Nico Krijno

item.title: Is There Too Much ‘Mental Health’ Awareness in the United States?
item.description: Has the term become so expansive as to be meaningless?
item.dc:creator: Huw Green
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie. Photographs from Getty Images

item.title: Mental Health in America: The Politics of ‘Insight’
item.description: Psychiatry too often ignores how a patient’s perspective can depend on culture, race, ethnicity and faith.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Aviv
item.media:credit: Katrien De Blauwer

item.title: Yvon Chouinard Is the Founder of Patagonia. He’s Also My ‘Dirtbag’ Friend.
item.description: Yvon Chouinard has given away his company in his fight to save the planet.
item.dc:creator: Tom Brokaw
item.media:credit: Laure Joliet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yvon Chouinard in the original Tin Shed, the blacksmith shop where he forged pitons for climbing.

item.title: Sweden’s Far Right Is Rising
item.description: The idea of Sweden as a land of equal opportunity, safe from the plagues of extreme left or extreme right that haunt other countries, is gone.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Asbrink
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of the Sweden Democrats political party during its election night rally.

item.title: “Historical Ecology” Can Help Us Save Our Oceans, Now
item.description: “Historical ecology” can help us save the seas.
item.dc:creator: John Waldman

item.title: Glenn Youngkin Is Playing a Dangerous Game
item.description: The governor believes he needs to cater to and actually support election questioners and deniers to have a shot at leading the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Glenn Youngkin of Virginia, speaking in Michigan at a “Red Wave Party.”

item.title: ‘Serial’ Investigates Why Adnan Syed Was Released From Prison
item.description: After decades of proclaiming his innocence and a podcast series dedicated to his case, a Mr. Syed won a reversal of his murder conviction.
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed, the subject of the first season of “Serial,” leaving Baltimore City Circuit Court after a judge overturned his conviction. He had served 23 years in prison.

item.title: Ultramarathon Runners Won’t Give Up Their Sport
item.description: Last year, the ultramarathon governing body dumped many multiday races from their catalog. So a group of fringe runners created their own championship, and just kept running.
item.dc:creator: Jared Beasley
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Race participants start the race for the first annual GOMU 48-Hour World Championships, an ultramarathon in Hainesport, N.J.

item.title: How a Quebec Lithium Mine May Help Make Electric Cars Affordable
item.description: The project also illustrates how difficult it is to get lithium out of the ground and break China’s dominance in processing the metal and turning it into batteries.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Brendan George Ko For The New York Times

item.title: Hurricane Fiona Batters Turks and Caicos as a Category 3 Storm
item.description: Fiona strengthened early Tuesday after knocking out power to most of Puerto Rico and bringing heavy rain to the Dominican Republic.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ricardo Rojas/Reuters
item.media:description: Debris on the seashore of Punta Cana, Dominican Republic, on Monday, as Hurricane Fiona passed through.

item.title: Egypt Feels Pain of Global Disruptions Wrought by War and Pandemic
item.description: The country’s economy has been very hard hit by cascading crises which have disrupted worldwide trade.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dates and other dried fruit on sale at a market in central Cairo. In March, the Egyptian central bank devalued the currency by about 14 percent and prices shot up.

item.title: From Coronation to Funeral: Bookends to the Life of a Queen, and a Generation
item.description: For 70 years, Elizabeth II was the anchor of a nation’s identity. Charles III now will take on, or recast, that role.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: PA Images, via Getty Images; Pool photo by Frank Augstein
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth’s coronation in 1953, and her funeral on Monday.

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: IUD Insertion: What to Know and Expect
item.description: Intrauterine devices are highly effective, but some women find insertion painful. Here’s how to prepare.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How Black Women Can Interpret Those Scary Health Statistics
item.description: Doomsday headlines are nothing new. But over time they can damage your mental health if you’re not careful.
item.dc:creator: Jacquelynn Kerubo
item.media:credit: Hélène Baum

item.title: Are Plan B and Body Weight Interconnected?
item.description: Researchers have looked into why and how weight influences emergency contraception but have come up against several unknowns. Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How to Recognize and Treat Perimenopause Symptoms
item.description: We break down the signs, causes and treatment options for five common symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Monica Garwood
item.media:credit: Monica Garwood

item.title: Their Dad Was Like a Brother. Now Pacman Jones Is Family.
item.description: Adam Jones and Chris Henry were once N.F.L. poster athletes for misdeeds. Raising Henry’s children alongside his own, Jones is hoping to help them all avoid the same mistakes.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:credit: Megan Jelinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adam Jones (who is known widely as Pacman), left, DeMarcus Henry, middle, and Chris Henry Jr., right, at West Clermont High’s football stadium in Batavia, Ohio.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
